title: Tottenham boss Mauricio Pochettino dismisses 'bottlers' label and insists they are punching above their weight
text:
Sport Tottenham boss Mauricio Pochettino dismisses 'bottlers' label and insists they are punching above their weight Like with Leicester a year ago, Spurs are the league leaders' closest challengers — despite only the sixth-highest wage bill Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Gary Lineker and Danny Murphy slam Spurs' defence Share this video Get football updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Mauricio Pochettino has hit back at critics who have branded his Tottenham side big-time bottlers. 
Boss Pochettino himself questioned his team’s title desire after Saturday's devastating defeat at Liverpool , when he said: “It is difficult to fight for the Premier League if you show a lack of desire to play for a win.” 
But the Argentinian says Spurs face an unfair fight because they don’t have the same resources as their rivals. 
He also took a swipe at pundits who have written off their title challenge by reminding them his club still sit second, even after being outplayed by Jurgen Klopp’s men. 
Asked what is missing as Tottenham’s title challenge appeared to crumble for a second successive season, he replied: “Maybe they [the pundits] know better than me. Spurs' title hopes were severely dented at Anfield but they are still the best of the rest (Photo: Getty) Read More Jermaine Jenas reveals hilarious way Roman Pavlyuchenko communicated with teammates 
“Sometimes it is about coping with the level and the competition. Today we were poor and feel very disappointed but be careful – it is only our third defeat in the Premier League and we are one point above Liverpool still.” 
Pochettino clearly believes that his side suffer from unfair expectations after creating hope among Spurs fans by over-achieving against rivals with deeper pockets. 
Spurs have only the sixth-highest wage-bill in the Premier League but have provided the most consistent challenge to Chelsea this season — just as they did to Leicester last season. 
“If you compare Tottenham with the other sides competing for the top four, maybe you should say, 'Wow, they deserve a lot of credit for where they are now,’” said Pochettino. Pochettino claims his club lack the resources of the rest of the top six (Photo: Action Images via Reuters) Read More 'Spurs were a shambles!' Match Of The Day duo slam defence after Liverpool defeat 
“We are in a different project to Liverpool, Chelsea, Manchester City, Manchester United and Arsenal. We are a club fighting for the Premier League with different tools in a different project. 
“We can’t compare with another team. Chelsea have a lot of players who know what it means to win and we are creating a winning mentality. I am disappointed today, but feel calm.” 
Pochettino acknowledged a lifeless first-half display at Anfield gave Spurs a mountain to climb against a Liverpool side that had won just once in 10 previous games. 
He said: “In the first 45 minutes you saw a team that is not ready to fight for the Premier League.” poll loading Will Tottenham finish in the top four? 0+ VOTES SO FAR
